episodes.summary: The vitamins-socks-wife combo was not quite Watergate but hints at something slightly creepy

episodes.title: Abuse of language keeps going forward
episodes.summary: Talking like a regular human being does not guarantee success

episodes.title: With jobs, make sure it pays to play
episodes.summary: To work for free means you value yourself at nothing, and that should make you feel bad indeed, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Words that warn you not to open an email
episodes.summary: What is the most off-putting thing you can write in the subject line of an email? Lucy Kellaway has compiled a list, in ascending order of obnoxiousness.

episodes.title: How the Rolling Stones keep time on their side
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says the stubbornly enduring group stays that way by flouting the rules in every success manual

episodes.title: The buzz of hot-desking in a coffee shop
episodes.summary: A ‘tall’ beige milk comes with unlimited table, chair and WiFi – but my back is killing me, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: The New Lady of Threadneedle Street
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says the position of chief operating officer signals a sad succumbing to the language of corporate America

episodes.title: A cup of tea may be the best way to engage employees
episodes.summary: People may come to dislike their jobs a little less, but seldom learn to love them

episodes.title: Wake up! Time for a good night’s sleep
episodes.summary: Sleeplessness is the biggest reason for me turning up crabby and inefficient in the mornings

episodes.title: Clearing your email is no act of virtue
episodes.summary: I have no folders, no system. That is because I don’t need one, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Graduates need a dose of reality
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says students need not change the world – getting a job will be an achievement

episodes.title: A meeting by any other name isn’t worth going to
episodes.summary: Calling it a summit, forum or ideas exchange doesn’t make a gathering any more important, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Grades don’t make the grade at the office
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says her test shows that those with firsts are neither better nor worse than those with seconds

episodes.title: Bad is the new good – except that it isn’t
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says the craze for taking something we all think is bad and telling us that it’s good is crazy

episodes.title: The business case for hiring the fat and the ugly
episodes.summary: Studies say the good looking are more successful but that is not a good way to recruit, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Elevator gossip rarely rises above the dull
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says the average office worker never relaxes in the lift

episodes.title: Worker bees should be left to bumble
episodes.summary: All this stuff about employee engagement is nonsense says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: When every day is April Fools' Day
episodes.summary: How do you spot an April Fools' Day joke from the real thing?

episodes.title: I’m still puzzling over my dream job
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says that a survey showing that teenagers in Britain want to pursue the ‘wrong’ careers was pointless

episodes.title: Facebook’s offices are too cool for women
episodes.summary: In insisting on a chilly conference room, Mark Zuckerberg is exhibiting dotcom dogmatism, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Worrying over your worth has no value
episodes.summary: No one complains about earning too much, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Office propositions are no clear-cut issue
episodes.summary: Now is the time to break my silence and tell my story of being sexually harassed at work, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: I can’t stop my cyber loafing
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says we need the equivalent of the stocks to persuade people to get off the net and get on with their work

episodes.title: Finally I’ve found some good corporate guff
episodes.summary: J&J’s ‘Our Credo’ got me excited. Alas, since it was written in 1943 there has been some slippage

episodes.title: End of the line for the landline
episodes.summary: The death of the old-style phone may help us individually but it loosens the bonds between us, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Wanted: a user’s guide to every boss
episodes.summary: If everybody knows what their manager’s little ways are, it is better all round, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: If I outsourced my work, would you care?
episodes.summary: The only risk is that the boss gets wind of the arrangement and cuts out the middleman

episodes.title: Take a stand on being more productive
episodes.summary: Last week I read a blog saying that sitting is the new smoking. It makes you fat and then it kills you. We must act, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Bosses fail the 10-year-old test
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says that a CEO ought to be able to explain what he does in a way a child can grasp

episodes.title: The first word in mangled meanings
episodes.summary: Bosses have been rampant in the world of bull, says the FT's Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: It’s time to stop stressing about stress
episodes.summary: It is quite wrong to think about it as the enemy, says the FT's Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Fatherhood is no degree in management
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says lessons learnt from family life can pay off at work

episodes.title: Why I’m proud to have no Klout
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says it is a nonsense to boil down something as qualitative as influence into a single number

episodes.title: Heard the one about women at the office?
episodes.summary: If laughter varies with gender, it varies even more with power, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Starbucks’ tea takeover is a grande of guff
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says the ubiquitous coffee chain cannot be forgiven for the way it grinds out its message

episodes.title: Marriages and jobs require work and love
episodes.summary: When it comes to the quest for the perfect match, it helps to keep your expectations real, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Time-wasting tips have wasted my time
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway finds that apparently a game of ‘Angry Birds’ is good for us

episodes.title: New workers want the same things we did
episodes.summary: The world of work is supposed to have changed beyond recognition since I started out on a bank's graduate training programme three decades ago, but actually it hasn’t. For graduate trainees, nothing of any importance has changed at all.

episodes.title: Embrace the network effect
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says alumni connections are not a problem at all – in fact they are a thoroughly good thing.

episodes.title: The question with interviews is why we bother
episodes.summary: Study after study shows an interview is not much better than picking people at random.

episodes.title: A rifle through my colleagues’ drawers
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says it’s not just the objects that are telling – it’s the juxtaposition

episodes.title: For creativity, forget the funky office
episodes.summary: With design so overbearing at Google’s London HQ, the individual can’t get a look in, says the FT's Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Road test CEOs to avoid corporate crashes
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says that top executives should take an annual hubris test

episodes.title: Good enough is better than perfection
episodes.summary: Anyone batty enough to aim for perfection in their work isn’t a force for good. Such obsession comes with a dark underside.

episodes.title: Why I can’t ‘like’ Facebook popularity contest
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says the joke should be on the even more stupid people who voice their approval in their millions

episodes.title: Why I’m inspired by the veteran Cosmo girl
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway discovers that Helen Gurley Brown had a great deal of exceedingly sensible, realistic things to say about work

episodes.title: Jobs, motherhood and varieties of wrong
episodes.summary: The FT's Lucy Kellaway says that there is no balance. It’s a continuous, fluid game of survival, the rules of which are unclear

episodes.title: London’s Olympics are a workers’ curse
episodes.summary: To stage this festival of sporting competitiveness every other sort of competition is being stifled says the FT's Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Why do we believe we get what we pay for?
episodes.summary: More expensive does not necessarily mean better, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Burberry chief’s top mix of brand and bunkum
episodes.summary: The FT's Lucy Kellaway says that Angela Ahrendts’ language meets the most important criterion for jargon – it is utterly impenetrable.

episodes.title: Ball boys demonstrate power of training
episodes.summary: Wimbledon’s teenage volunteer training has produced strong results, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Don’t aim for the top unless you feel lucky
episodes.summary: We can study Bill Gates all we like but we’re not going to end up where he is, says the FT's Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: The thin line between thick skin and complacency
episodes.summary: It is a CEO’s job to take things very personally, says the FT's Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: A dose of dullness is good for business
episodes.summary: Being boring is no barrier to great leadership, says the FT's Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Manual work holds the key to spiritual bliss
episodes.summary: Upholstery has shown Lucy Kellaway that losing yourself is a far better idea than finding yourself

episodes.title: Beware the wild management consultants
episodes.summary: The story of Bain and the buffalo makes one question business travel says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Small mistakes attract the biggest trouble
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway on why smart people will always make stupid errors

episodes.title: My logo obsession is more than a game
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway discovers that our stock of brands is so ingrained that they have become part of who we are

episodes.title: Flattery will get you what you want
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway argues that facts have little traction in the art of persuasion

episodes.title: Affiliations matter more than achievement
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway on why the ambitious should go for prestige every time

episodes.title: Break bad habits and you’ll deliver profits
episodes.summary: No amount of huddles will crack Royal Mail’s rubber band problem, says the FT's Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: The female of the species is more scary than the male
episodes.summary: Successful women are more frightening than men, says the FT's Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Online life can teach us about the office
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellway on whether virtual working might one day happen properly

episodes.title: The perils of parting shots
episodes.summary: Why listening to departing employees is foolish

episodes.title: Office tittle-tattle makes having a job a pleasure
episodes.summary: The thing that is killing the finest sort of gossip is the internet: email, Facebook and Twitter.

episodes.title: Women’s inequality isn’t what it used to be
episodes.summary: Everything I see at work (apart from surveys) tells me that there are more women doing better and having a better time.

episodes.title: Meetings of minds are effectively a tool for dulling them
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway on why working alone is the best way to get things done

episodes.title: The fine art of penning your own ‘brief bio’
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway on her eight rules for this trickiest of literary genres

episodes.title: UBS’s silly menu leaves a bad taste
episodes.summary: It is time to worry when companies write witless things and then hand them to their customers, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: If you have to reject me, tell me straight
episodes.summary: No one appreciates hollow good wishes from someone who is telling them to shove off, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: If you want adult behaviour, treat people like babies
episodes.summary: Lloyds bank has found a new way of saving money. It has banned all staff from travelling on the third week of every month.  If this is a good idea, a similar system should be deployed for all the other ways in which We Are Not Wise with our time, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: The 2011 guff awards
episodes.summary: The judging is now complete and Lucy Kellaway is ready to announce the winners of her annual business jargon awards.

episodes.title: Social networks upend office etiquette
episodes.summary: What is acceptable and what is shameless? The answer is that no one has the foggiest – we are all making it up as we go along, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Money’s too tight to mention if you have lots of it
episodes.summary: It is surprisingly hard to be good at having money – harder than acquiring it in the first place. The perfect amount of money is when you hardly have to think about it at all, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: We all deserve to be told the terrible truth
episodes.summary: ‘Protected conversations’ between employees and bosses are a good idea but they won’t make any difference in practice, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: A guide to life in the fast cycle lane
episodes.summary: Thinking strategically about your life isn’t necessarily such a great idea, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Stick to the rules and abusing your colleagues is OK
episodes.summary: So long as top people in the City are continuing to behave in an uncivilised fashion, the world as we know it isn’t coming to an end, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Copying, the mother of the best inventions
episodes.summary: No one seems interested in teaching us how to get better at mimicry, despite it being the key to success, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Management guff lands in China
episodes.summary: When the guff germ arrives big time in China, my prediction is that they will be better at dealing with it than westerners, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: BlackBerry blackout left me happily unlinked
episodes.summary: Most email messages are exceedingly stupid, and none more so than the ones that arrive from LinkedIn, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Everyone benefits from a beast in the boardroom
episodes.summary: All companies need someone on board who stirs things up and couldn’t care less what people think, just don’t confuse it with ego, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Forget doing the ‘math’ and stick to proper English
episodes.summary: All sorts of things are just plain wrong when translated from maths to business talk, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Pretenders to power are the most dangerous
episodes.summary: Power may corrupt, but absolute power corrupts much less than partial power – as too many lower down the pecking order show, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: My cure for an outbreak of weak excuse tendency
episodes.summary: Sufferers from WET aren’t skiving or lying; they just have an inadequate notion of what it means to be reliable, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Bartz flubs her lines as she leaves the Yahoo stage
episodes.summary: The sacking of Carol Bartz last week made theatre of the most superior kind. Watching the former chief executive of Yahoo go down spitting obscenities was exhilarating in an immediate sort of way, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Do teddies have a place in the boardroom?
episodes.summary: Research from an expert in ethics at Harvard University suggests people behave better when teddy bears are in the room, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Chief Googler’s ‘amazing’ clichés are dull and void
episodes.summary: Larry Page’s thinking on his decision to spend $12.5bn on some mobile handsets, patents and set-top boxes is woolly at best, says Lucy Kellway.

episodes.title: Age-old bonds make the office tick
episodes.summary: Is working with people of different ages really a problem?

episodes.title: Six little words and one very big question
episodes.summary: What keeps you in your job? What would your six-word answer be?

episodes.title: Anti-PowerPoint revolutionaries unite
episodes.summary: The ubiquitous piece of software can leave one feeling grumpy and passive and in no frame of mind for proper work, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Unrequited love and corporate idiocy
episodes.summary: When the new head of Tesco in the UK said he wanted staff to love customers, I followed up by visiting my local store, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Cheers to those with a glass half-empty
episodes.summary: In business, optimism is good and pessimism bad. Optimists have a monopoly on success, on happiness and even on longevity. Pessimists, with their long faces and dark thoughts are pariahs, thought fit for nothing in the gung-ho corporate world except possibly careers in journalism (where bad news is good news). Otherwise, they have a choice between the couch, the closet or the comedy circuit.

episodes.title: You’ve got mail but you need to get your life back
episodes.summary: Everyone agrees that we spend too much of our lives e-mailing. Everyone agrees that the answer is to write fewer, shorter, clearer messages. Everyone has known this for years. Yet instead of getting better, the problem goes on getting worse.

episodes.title: A need to please can get you into trouble
episodes.summary: Two different women, both of them up to their eyes in different sorts of trouble, last week put forward the same excuse to explain lapses in their behaviour. Each said she was suffering from a new debilitating condition – a compulsion to please people.

episodes.title: Path to happiness runs through the office
episodes.summary: It is a terrific relief to find that the true path to happiness involves doing what most of us do most of the time, whether we like it or not – work

episodes.title: E-mail contract is not worth the kilobytes
episodes.summary: Legal disclaimers on e-mails are not only unenforced but unenforceable – making one wonder why they are so popular

episodes.title: The wonders worked by womanhood
episodes.summary: Lagarde is right to play the female card – this is the best time there has been to be a woman with talent, charm, and an appetite for advancement, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Despite the offer, I won’t fill in for DSK
episodes.summary: I don’t like the idea of deputising for someone who was sorting out the financial crisis and might have been president of France, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Must I remember my kids’ ages just to log on?
episodes.summary: In the early days of computers I never forgot my password because the top secret word I’d chosen was ‘Kellaway’, which I found could be effortlessly recalled even in the most fraught moments, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: The dull names of those who rose
episodes.summary: Research shows that with CEOs overwhelmingly having boring first names, the drearier the moniker, the greater the success – and that diversity is bunkum says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Drivel is in the detail with CEO pay
episodes.summary: The reams of justification for executive remuneration are mind-numbing and likely to make one succumb through sheer weariness, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: You might be a genius but I wouldn’t tell you so
episodes.summary: Even though I prefer to have genius status granted for big things, I’m prepared to accept it for any achievement at all, even for pressing send on my computer, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Tablets to cure our smartphone sicknesses
episodes.summary: Last Monday, when Kerry McCarthy MP got up to speak in the House of Commons she made history – not for the words she spoke, but for reading them off her iPad.

episodes.title: Writing is on the wall for ‘customer care’
episodes.summary: A letter posted on a lavatory wall to amuse with its verbosity highlights the deficiencies of another missive by a virtuoso at apology – and guff.

episodes.title: China rekindles fondness for western ways
episodes.summary: In accepting the invitation to go on a debating tour, I had expected to return with a mind full of management ideas and a suitcase full of rip-off handbags.

episodes.title: Business leaders are worse than they think
episodes.summary: When it comes to describing their dark sides, leaders feel bound by one rule: any weakness is perfectly admissible, so long as it is really a strength.

episodes.title: Pen and paper: the forgotten management tool
episodes.summary: Last week I went out for a pizza with a man I hadn’t seen for a while. The bill was low; I picked it up. Two days later, a small, cream envelope arrived on my doormat. Inside was a folded piece of paper on which he had written a short note saying how much he had enjoyed the occasion.

episodes.title: Female quotas would target the wrong women
episodes.summary: If you are listening to this during office hours on Monday, you can think of me sitting at a large table engaged in deep discussion about dividends, internal controls and appetites for risk. With me will be my fellow directors of a FTSE 100 company, 11 of us in all: nine men and two women.

episodes.title: America’s Next Top Student
episodes.summary: She is beautiful, rich and famous. She has two television shows, one of which is named after her. She’s got her own foundation that helps deprived girls. She’s been to bed with Barack Obama. She is taking a course at Harvard Business School on how to be an entrepreneur.

episodes.title: Talk like a loser and you might win
episodes.summary: When I watched Tim Armstrong on CNN last week talking about the brilliance of his decision to buy the Huffington Post, I found I didn’t believe a word he was saying.

episodes.title: Two banks, a conman and a homeless bloke
episodes.summary: Last week, there were two stories in the papers about bankers being taken for a ride by conmen and nutters. Both tales were profoundly enjoyable: seeing investment bankers with egg on their faces is always cheering. They were also enjoyably profound, making one question what bankers get up to all day and which talents are needed to perform those tasks well.

episodes.title: A good employer offers more than Botox
episodes.summary:
Last week, Fortune magazine published its latest survey of the 100 best companies to work for in the US. 

As I have never worked at any of them I can’t offer first hand corroboration of the rankings – though in 1981 I did try to get a job at Boston Consulting Group (rated number two in the Fortune list), but was rejected after letting slip in an interview that I had no idea what a learning curve was.

episodes.title: Pointless conditions should not apply
episodes.summary: I was sitting on a train coming back to London after a board meeting in Cardiff. Life felt good: the meeting had ended a bit earlier than I’d feared and I was just getting stuck into a gin and tonic and a packet of Quavers when the ticket inspector came round. I handed her my ticket, which she pronounced not valid.

episodes.title: Finnish lesson on principles for Goldman
episodes.summary: Lloyd Blankfein is in need of advice on the principles of business. Fortunately, I have just the man to give it to him: Hannu Penttilä, a Finnish shopkeeper who runs a chain of department stores.

episodes.title: My awards for management guff
episodes.summary: At the beginning of every year I hand out prizes to companies and individuals who have shown the greatest flair in butchering the English language or in talking through their hats during the previous 12 months.

episodes.title: Better to waste time at the office
episodes.summary: Even though it’s a weekday and during working hours, I’m in bed. The reason for such slovenliness is that I’m not feeling my best. Too unwell to feel like getting up, yet not so unwell that I can’t move my fingers over a keyboard.

episodes.title: Two memos divided by understanding
episodes.summary: This week I’ve decided to focus on two things that are always popular at this time of year. Layoffs and stand-up rows.

episodes.title: A glimpse of ambassadorial life
episodes.summary: Last Monday I had a delightful lunch with the turkey ambassador. He didn’t appear to know anything much about Ankara or care whether Turkey joined the European Union, but seemed more interested in what people eat for Christmas. He was the chef, Marco Pierre White, who had just been given the title by Bernard Matthews, the biggest British turkey producer, and was therefore flying the flag of the battery bird.

episodes.title: Better to save face than look in the mirror
episodes.summary: At a party last week I met a man who told me he had just lost his job. I commiserated, but he said it was OK, he was well out of it. He explained that his boss was a fool who could not cope with having an underling who was far brighter and more charismatic than him. The man looked perfectly cheerful and reassured me that his pay-off had been large, and the move was his employer’s loss.

episodes.title: Breaking the glass ceiling at home
episodes.summary: On the front of Wednesday’s Financial Times was a picture of Kate Middleton smiling adoringly at the future king of England and giving every impression of delight over her new job as the nation’s foremost corporate wife.

episodes.title: Don’t give hiring a moment’s notice
episodes.summary:
Wearing socks on the outside of your shoes makes you less likely to slip on icy paths.

Promoting people at random makes companies more efficient.

These two hypotheses were among the winners of this year’s Ig Nobel prizes – handed out by Improbable Research, an organisation set up to promote academic work that makes you laugh, then think.

episodes.title: Being happy is a serious handicap
episodes.summary: There is a teenage boy I know who worries me quite a lot. He was born to a good family with plenty of money. He is extroverted and optimistic; people appear to like him. He’s relatively easy on the eye and reasonably bright. His health is good and he can kick, hit and catch balls of various shapes and sizes. He does not smoke, or take drugs, or do any more binge drinking than the next person.

episodes.title: The thief, his victim and the company laptop
episodes.summary: The only problem with losing stuff is not that harm is done, it is that people fear that harm will be done and the loss does not look pretty in the papers, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Glass ceiling in management drivel is broken
episodes.summary: It is usually men who talk more management nonsense, but Lucy Kellaway finds they are no longer the only ones capable of talking guff

episodes.title: Listening to customers can be bad business
episodes.summary: Management accepting humiliation in order to satisfy customers seems like a good thing but Gap’s climbdown on its new logo is feeble, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: We need more CEOs willing to speak out
episodes.summary: Everyone lives in mortal dread of getting into trouble – CEOs are all shacked up together in a glass house in which no stones ever get thrown, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Power posing and flattery beat an MBA any day
episodes.summary: To make it, you simply have to fake it, according to Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Time to spit out more praise for Apple
episodes.summary: The exchange between Steve Jobs and Chelsea Isaacs prompts Lucy Kellaway  to congratulate him on his clarity, tetchiness and for being completely in the right

episodes.title: Words to describe the glory of Apple
episodes.summary:
Like most Brits, I find success in others pretty hard to cope with. When that success is  combined with good looks, I can’t tolerate it at all.

Apple’s continued glory eats away at me like a maggot at my core.

episodes.title: Why CEOs cry all the way to the bank
episodes.summary:
Bob Diamond is full of energy and enthusiasm. He likes taking risks. He is determined: he knows what he wants and goes for it. He is fearless, cheerfully taking on a job he has little experience of. He speaks (relatively) simply. He has been known to throw tantrums. He is greedy and always wants more.

I’ve never met him, but on the strength of what I’ve been reading about him I’m absolutely confident that he’s going to make an excellent new chief at Barclays. This is because he accords perfectly with a brand new theory of leadership that is surprising, radical, yet utterly compelling. This theory says that the best CEOs are just like toddlers.

episodes.title: Twitter is no way to manage a smelly mess
episodes.summary: On the bank holiday weekend, the political satirist Armando Iannucci was driving along the M40 to spend a couple of days in Snowdonia and stopped off at a Starbucks on the way. As he is a man who likes to record all his thoughts on Twitter, he dispatched this message to his 80,000 followers: “Still surprised that, despite their market dominance, Starbucks haven’t eliminated the slight smell of lavatory you get as you enter.”

episodes.title: Personal life has invaded the office
episodes.summary: Over the past decade there has been a steady onward march of objects, activities and emotions from hearth to cubicle, so there is now almost nothing left that belongs entirely at home.

episodes.title: Antidote to the dreariness of modern life
episodes.summary: Last night I did what I always do when I am feeling jaded - I got out my boxed-set of Mad Men and immersed myself in the hedonistic, glamorous world of Maddison Avenue in the 1960s, when all women were a 38 triple-D cup, all men drank scotch from lunchtime till bedtime, everyone chain-smoked and fornicated whenever they got the chance.

episodes.title: Why financiers are leaders in drivel
episodes.summary: The e-mail was waiting for me on my return from holiday, just as I knew it would be. Shortly before I went away, I had written a column in which I had borrowed not merely someone else’s idea but his very words. At the time I thought I’d get away with it, but in the middle of the night had woken in a sweat. In the age of the internet, plagiarists nearly always get punished.

episodes.title: Nice dud is key to office harmony
episodes.summary: Last Tuesday, during the final assembly of the year at my daughter’s school, pupils said  goodbye to a teacher who was being elbowed out. Miss T was famous for her feebleness at imparting knowledge; the new broom of a head had decided it would make more sense to give the job to someone who could teach instead.

episodes.title: It’s time to sack job appraisals
episodes.summary: Last week an e-mail went round the office touting for suggestions on ways to improve our performance appraisal system. My suggestion is dead easy and dirt cheap: get rid of the whole thing and replace it with nothing at all.

episodes.title: Don’t just dress down on Fridays
episodes.summary: In Britain they are cutting about a million jobs. In France, they have axed the Bastille Day garden party. All governments are looking for ways big and small to cut spending. But there is a better way that no one has yet considered: cut Fridays.

episodes.title: It is time for the gender gap to be kicked into touch?
episodes.summary: The only difference between male and female managers, says Lucy, is that women are less confident and more hung up on approval.

episodes.title: BP has become the company we all love to hate
episodes.summary: It's not just Americans or lefties or environmentalists who now hate BP. Everyone else seems to as well.

episodes.title: A self-help guide for Sir Terry Leahy
episodes.summary: Lucy's list of key "don'ts" for a retiring chief executive

episodes.title: Principles for living we could all do without
episodes.summary: Lucy on Bridgewater chief, Ray Dalio, and the list of his top 300 rules for life.

episodes.title: When the FSA came calling
episodes.summary: A summons to a 90-minute interview with the financial regulator sends Lucy reeling through the five stages of grief

episodes.title: It's the little things we should fret about
episodes.summary: One of the comedies of working life is pretending to care about the big things, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Fabulous Fab is far scarier than you think
episodes.summary: Is Fabrice Tourre one of the most boastful men in the world, or is the Goldman Sachs trader a man who looks dispassionately at himself and is well aware of his weaknesses?

episodes.title: Ash cloud helped productivity
episodes.summary: It was miraculous what the volcano did to conferences, meetings and business trips.

episodes.title: The joys of long service
episodes.summary: Does 25 years at this paper make me a disgrace, asks Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: My first law of success: a big lucky break
episodes.summary: Most successful people have had big lucky breaks at birth and a succession of smaller ones thereafter

episodes.title: Generation game plays out on Facebook
episodes.summary: The gap between the Facebook/non-Facebook generation is wider than the gap between previous generations.

episodes.title: You can’t always get what you want
episodes.summary: The current trend of using rock bands as models for business school study is deeply flawed.

episodes.title: Why feedback forms leave me fed up
episodes.summary: The problem with feedback? The wrong questions are asked at the wrong time to people who generally are in no frame of mind to answer them properly. But spontaneous feedback can be a good thing.

episodes.title: A corporate calendar that is so last year
episodes.summary: ‘A client a day’ makes no sense at all, especially in a business where people often work with the same client for months on end, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Why insensitive bosses make more sense
episodes.summary: This is the single most sensible word I’ve seen on the flabby subject of leadership in at least a decade, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: My new motto: Nomina Rutrum Rutrum
episodes.summary: Latin gives oomph, partly because it lends an air of learning but also because most people have to look it up, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Memory doesn’t matter when you have the net
episodes.summary: The only essential things to remember are one’s computer login, pin number and the names of a few workmates, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Clooney won’t do in business
episodes.summary: I can think of three possible explanations why in mainstream corporate life in the UK and the US, the ugly mug rules, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: My proven formula for cheerfulness
episodes.summary: The most depressing day of the year is upon us. But Lucy Kellaway says she has found a better way to keep up morale than the motivational gurus

episodes.title: Why forecasters should stick to the weather
episodes.summary: Cold air has been blowing out of the Arctic, and hot air has been blowing out of the mouths of business forecasters, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Good year for management guff
episodes.summary: Even in bad times, some can still push the envelope and go the extra mile when it comes to talking bull, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Tomes to make you groan
episodes.summary: There is no shortage of bad business books, but Lucy Kellaway feels that giving them as ironic presents to bankers would be irresponsible

episodes.title: Give office idiocy Dada treatment
episodes.summary: I come across a lot of angry people in the course of my work, writes Lucy Kellaway. They take exception to anodyne things written by me.

episodes.title: Rebels who look ridiculous
episodes.summary: A bright tie, red socks, a flash of crimson in the lining of a suit – these attempts to stand out in the office smack of desperation, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: How to land on your feet when speaking in public
episodes.summary: What Lucy and J-Lo have in common; and how to avoid boring your audience when speaking in public

episodes.title: When too much information harms the office
episodes.summary: Staff are responding to overload by not digesting anything. No one reads e-mails any more – except from the boss, writes Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: The return of managerial bone-headedness
episodes.summary: The bear market in bull may be over but the bear market in courage is not. Fear and paranoia are even more a part of corporate life, argues Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: For better or for worse, but not for work
episodes.summary: To allow husbands and wives to co-work has always been a bad idea financially, socially, practically and emotionally, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: When a longer working life is good for us all
episodes.summary: Work is a bit like taking exercise. It can be boring and stressful while you are doing it but it is preferable to not working, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Why ‘chillaxing’ isn’t cool
episodes.summary: Chilling is seen by today’s children as the natural order of things. However, taking it easy in the office is not a good idea, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Taboo or not taboo? Some new office guidelines
episodes.summary: A search for the sacrosanct subjects of the workplace was almost fruitless as most of the old strictures at work are on the way out, but there are still some no-go areas, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: The perils of opening your medicine cabinet at work
episodes.summary: Gordon Brown’s questioning over whether he takes pills to cope with the pressure reveals the new taboo in the workplace, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: How to be a top female boss
episodes.summary: Anna Wintour's longevity in the fashion industry and hard-nosed approach provide a useful model for women executives

episodes.title: Drug dealers are perfect gurus in a recession
episodes.summary: With their ruthlessness and brilliance at managing cash flow, hustlers such as the reformed 50 Cent can provide useful lessons to executives, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Letting the office go to the dogs
episodes.summary: Bring your dog to work day may uncover some uncomfortable office truths, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Wash away management’s verbal germs
episodes.summary: In my book, cleanliness is not next to godliness.  Necessary up to a point, but quite dull, and not something that deserves a place in management literature.

episodes.title: Women in the boardroom
episodes.summary: After decades of discussing women in the boardroom we should have gained enough confidence to go post-PC, argues Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Take it easy about ageing
episodes.summary: As contemporaries seemed to have stopped playing the obsessive game of age comparison - its time to join them, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: The missed trick in the new pay reality
episodes.summary: With employees paid to stay at home, the relationships between work and leisure, and money and no money are breaking down, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: School exams fail the office test
episodes.summary: They teach lessons about work that you need to unlearn pretty smartly if you want to get ahead in business, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Kudos to bosses who use praise wisely
episodes.summary: At a time when no one can afford to reward people with more money, to reward them with handouts of 'what a star' would seem a no-brainer, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Underdog tale sheds light on pushy parenting
episodes.summary: It does one good to fail in a small way. It means one then has to work hard to catch up, and that one may have a fresher way of doing things, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: How a thief gave me 10 reasons to be grateful
episodes.summary: It was a great morale boost that this time I was victim rather than perpetrator, and people have been astoundingly sympathetic, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: How to take safe revenge on the boss
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway says anti-boss rage is more in vogue than it has ever been in her lifetime. She watches the display with alternate surges of glee and discomfort

episodes.title: When chore-chore means war-war
episodes.summary: The trick is not for husbands and wives to get to a 50:50 share when doing the housework. It is to stop counting and to stop minding, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Career counsellors should find a new job
episodes.summary: The whole idea of advice is hopeless: the best tests in the world would not help, as there is no formula for matching round pegs to round holes, writes Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Work is the subject songwriters are labouring to avoid
episodes.summary: Work has been overlooked in pop lyrics: there are office novels, office sitcoms and office movies, but almost no office songs, writes Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: There is a Fred Goodwin or Dick Fuld in all of us
episodes.summary: There are many theories about the mess we are in, but it is simply what you get when you take human beings and put them in an organisation, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Lord Lucan and the vanished charm of desks
episodes.summary: What has happened to the office desk over the past few hundred years tells of the fall of the craftsman and the rise of Ikea but it also says much about what has happened to the penpusher and office worker, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Management metaphors are out for the count
episodes.summary: I have seen an article that marks the first evidence from the management guff industry that a soft approach is finally on its way out and a hard one is on its way in.

episodes.title: Welcome back, semicolon; cu l8r, informality
episodes.summary: The pendulum has swung away from slouchy language towards correct usage of punctuation in emails, helped by the recession.

episodes.title: Stay smart and pull your socks up
episodes.summary: To survive this economic downturn we need to smarten up and buckle down. We really need to get some work under our belts.

episodes.title: My new guilt as a selfish working mother
episodes.summary: An idea about the happiness of happiness that had given me solace these last two years has been rudely overturned by the conclusions of a report, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: I have fallen into recession web of fear
episodes.summary: Through blogs, websites and e-mails the economic ills of the world are fed to us on a drip all day long, multiplying troubles everywhere, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Nothing to fear from your inner child
episodes.summary: I dare say the US president hoped his words would resonate beyond the toy cupboard and sweetie jar, but even so they are feeble advice, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Memories of my $10m trading blunder
episodes.summary: The first episode of a business reality television programme rammed home the message that being a trader is the worst job in the world. But it is in reality TV that Gordon Brown could really make his mark in hard times, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: A cool reaction to colleagues' colds
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway finds she has little time for those who abandon work for their beds because of a cold, despite the chill wind of recession blowing outside

episodes.title: Twaddle thrives amid the turmoil
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway laments that  management twaddle and gobbledygook haven't faded away with the recession

episodes.title: Expect to get dirty when a name is mud
episodes.summary: If your occupation involves making off with money from investors, then it is proper the name Made-off reflects that. There is a fine tradition at work here.

episodes.title: Money is the new secret of a happy job
episodes.summary: When your job is at risk and your savings are a shadow of their former selves, the search for meaning at work becomes meaningless in itself, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: A risky hug in recessionary times
episodes.summary: In the cause of research for a novel, Lucy Kellaway explores the world of internet adultery, and finds that, as the market for banking jobs goes cold, the market for adultery is getting hotter.

episodes.title: The worst since 1929?
episodes.summary: Newspaper articles in these tumultuous, fatal, not-seen-since-the-Great-Depression times are so tightly packed with cliche that it is hard to do anything other than join in, says Lucy Kellaway. But she says we must be careful not to overstate things.

episodes.title: A supercalifragilistic answer
episodes.summary: If bankers want to understand the global financial crisis, what better way, Lucy Kellaway suggests, than to watch classic film Mary Poppins.  They will find a film, she says, that manages to be 'soothing, perspicacious and upbeat all at once.' Time to listen to your inner chimney sweep.

episodes.title: Flatulence is no longer tolerated
episodes.summary: As the global financial crisis deepens, Lucy Kellaway says the glory days of the management bullshit industry are well and truly over. But she admits the return of sense may not be entirely welcome.

episodes.title: This novel approach to the chief's role is pure fiction
episodes.summary: What chief executives could learn from reading novels

episodes.title: Why salaries are the final taboo
episodes.summary: The global movement to end salary secrecy is flawed, says Lucy Kellaway. It is relative, not actual, pay levels that determine happiness, and sometimes it is better not to know

episodes.title: Advice for ex-bankers with long positions in Mars bars
episodes.summary: Should we be sickened at the news of formerly well-paid Lehman bankers jostling with their vending cards for the last Mars Bars? Lucy Kellaway asks just what kind of character is needed to survive the financial meltdown and to find another job.

episodes.title: Teen troublemakers and business parents
episodes.summary: If you are a business leader your children can screw up as much as they like without harming your career prospects at all, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: The pen is mightier...
episodes.summary: Lucy Kellaway goes back to school with a brand new pen lid, which offers a lifetime of pleasure - putting modern gadgets to shame

episodes.title: The City lawyer, the intern and the strip club
episodes.summary: You don't need to be a lawyer to know that strip club, summer intern and clumsy pass all up to trouble, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Dying wish to spend more time in the office
episodes.summary: Thinking about death generally encourages people to come up with dodgy philosophies about life, says Lucy Kellway. The best way of living is not to think of death at all

episodes.title: A strange kind of capitalism
episodes.summary: Mervyn King, governor of the Bank of England, set a 'lousy' example by turning down a pay rise, says Lucy Kellaway. For a capitalist economy to work, we all need to believe that more money is a good thing.

episodes.title: My guide to snoopology
episodes.summary: Easily the most satisfying job I've done in two dozen years as a journalist was writing a series of articles describing the offices of famous chief executives. For a brief period, I was allowed to indulge my natural nosiness - and get paid for it.

episodes.title: Board battles won on playing fields
episodes.summary: Nearly half of the chief executives of Britain's biggest companies have gained awards for their prowess in the field of sport, says Lucy Kellaway.

episodes.title: Shock of BPC: before personal computers
episodes.summary: To mark the retirement of Bill Gates, inventor of Windows, Lucy Kellaway decides to turn off her computer and Blackberry, and write and think with a fountain pen. Can she survive?

episodes.title: When complaining to wrong person is right
episodes.summary: One might think that the American purposeful complaint is better than pointless bellyaching, but in fact both can prove to be highly enjoyable.

episodes.title: A bouquet of office barbs
episodes.summary: I have been out collecting a botanical array of dangerous workplace blooms, words that can spoil our day, our week - or our career.

episodes.title: Letter-writing chiefs: you're fired
episodes.summary: I am running a competition in which a chief executive has to woo his customers with a letter. My finalists are Vikram Pandit and Johnnie Boden.

episodes.title: Marriage demands due diligence
episodes.summary: Being in love is like being on drugs. Do we let people who are off their heads on cocaine make important decisions? Of course not.

episodes.title: Aim low to find meaning at work
episodes.summary: The only answer to the growing problem of worker unhappiness is to stop trying to find a solution and get on with what you do.

episodes.title: Decade's spaced-out legacy in business
episodes.summary: Even though in offices 1968 did not happen until about 1988, the ideas of the 1960s still affect how we behave and think at work.

episodes.title: We'll never know how women would run the world
episodes.summary: In truth we don't have the foggiest idea what life would be like if women ran the show. So far we have only isolated, untypical examples.

episodes.title: If there were no losers, we wouldn't have any winners
episodes.summary: Win-win? Instead of pretending that everything is a win, the good leader needs to get better about wining and losing

episodes.title: Give managers the 'nanny test'
episodes.summary: It isn't easy to keep a person happy in a job that is poorly paid and involves much wiping of bottoms. Managing a nanny is management at its most extreme.

episodes.title: On my own monetary matters, nuttiness kicks in
episodes.summary: Knowing the difference between personal fiscal prudence and being a spendthrift is one thing. But being able to keep a tight rein on your personal spending is quite another.

episodes.title: Seven type's of rot
episodes.summary: 'Your call is important to us'... Lucy Kellaway provides a rot analysis of business talk, looking at phrases that mean the opposite of what they pretend to mean.

episodes.title: Trapped workers develop a line in doodling
episodes.summary: It is wrong to see doodling as something to do when bored. Instead, it is what we do when we are forced to listen to someone else.

episodes.title: Put an end to the trauma of the telephone
episodes.summary: E-mail is much derided for interrupting our day's work, but it is as nothing when compared to the noisy, intrusive, brutal phone.

episodes.title: Green holiday that makes me see red
episodes.summary: The National Trust gave its 5,000 employees a leap day holiday - but they had to spend time making their own homes more environmentally friendly. Should companies force us to be charitable?

episodes.title: Rekindling a 25-year bond
episodes.summary: At the annual get-together of the alumni of JPMorgan I realised that part of my life may have been weird but it was not an irrelevance, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Happiness is finding your inner receptionist
episodes.summary: When we were young we had something to prove. As we grow older, we realise that just as few doors are open to us as when we were young.

episodes.title: Unpolished exchanges put soul into shopping
episodes.summary: A local shoe mender has unknowingly supplied me with all the delightful things that large service companies are striving in vain to provide.

episodes.title: Accenture's next champion of waffle words
episodes.summary: An e-mail from Accenture's group chief executive is troubling because it shows top people write jargon even when they think no clients are looking.

episodes.title: Indulgence is no way to manage a bleating luvvie
episodes.summary: Artists are no different to any other profession; they need to be managed too, so they can go on getting better. Lucy Kellaway delves into the business-like approach that financier Guy Hands plans to take with musicians at EMI, and asks: should you be prepared to discipline a creative at the risk of losing them?

episodes.title: Bonuses for the incorrigibly childish
episodes.summary: The granting of investment bank bonuses is a ruinously expensive, tiring and highly political game in which almost everyone emerges a loser. Here's how the game works.

episodes.title: A New Year's resolution that will last
episodes.summary: What do workplace experts and coaches tell us about making new year resolutions? And can Lucy find one she can keep?

episodes.title: A year of breakthrough thinking from top twaddlists
episodes.summary: Lucy gives out her 2007 awards for management nonsense

episodes.title: Keep marriage counsellors out of the office
episodes.summary: At work I'm a pussycat, compliant and pathetically keen to please. At home I am a tyrant, brooking no opposition from anyone. So why do people think there are parralels between good marriages and good colleagues?

episodes.title: Express your anger - it is all the rage
episodes.summary: For me work is one long rage opportunity - starting with the fact that the machine that dispenses hot water for tea is on the blink.

episodes.title: Leaders in need of a good idea
episodes.summary: The title 'thought leader' offends for several reasons. And when the term is used there is usually no sign of any thinking or leading going on

episodes.title: The headhunters' disease
episodes.summary: Saying anything that makes any sense at all is enough to disqualify one from joining what practitioners call the 'executive search space'

episodes.title: Secret science of persuasion
episodes.summary: Has Lucy been getting it wrong for 600 columns? A US professor in psychology and marketing has explained how some campaigns can work, including plying your audience with caffeine

episodes.title: Reasons for being miserable at work
episodes.summary: The three things that really make most workers unhappy are actually rather basic - they are the work, the people and the general environment

episodes.title: The battle is lost, going forward
episodes.summary: Going backward: how the phrase 'going forward' has infected business conversation

episodes.title: Reasons for effing and blinding
episodes.summary: This column is about strong language, which explains why it contains some. Swearing can be useful in the office, but there are some rules you should follow.

episodes.title: Strap on the sensors and step out into the future
episodes.summary: Imagine a brave new world where electronic tagging of employees brings the study of management out of the dark ages. Lucy Kellaway peeks into a frightening future as scientists strive to answer why some companies and managers are so good - and others so bad.

episodes.title: The joy of fresh stationery, gossip and lattes with lids
episodes.summary: A new theory of happiness says the only reliable pleasures in life are the small ones. So what small pleasures can you find in an office?

episodes.title: A word in your ear
episodes.summary: Listening is really easy - any old fool can do it - so it can't therefore be a key skill for CEOs, argues Lucy Kellaway. So why do so many business leaders go on about it?

episodes.title: Why lies can save your office blushes
episodes.summary: The problem with being truthful about missing work is the reason can be embarrassing or implausible.

episodes.title: The real reason why there are fewer women at the top
episodes.summary: The glass ceiling or labyrinth fall short of explaining why women don't make it to the top. Perhaps, argues Lucy Kellaway, women should look at themselves.

episodes.title: Take a bracing dip in September's overflowing in-box
episodes.summary: Long ago, before e-mail, the return from holiday was a leisurely thing

episodes.title: We are not family
episodes.summary: 'We' doesn't imply teamwork or even people who like each other. It is just the mundane experience of office life

episodes.title: Fleeting pleasures of August without the A-team
episodes.summary: There are many reasons to be happy in the office in August - but needless e-mails from control freaks on holiday isn't one of them.

episodes.title: Just say No to the new managerial cult of Yes
episodes.summary: For people in any position of authority the ability to say no is the most important skill there is.

episodes.title: Some uncharitable thoughts on millionaire generosity
episodes.summary: Being generous as a millionaire doesn't make you different to the middle classes, says Lucy Kellaway. An act of true generosity is a rare event whether you are a millionaire or not.

episodes.title: Today's punishment is meted out with politesse
episodes.summary: A corporate bollocking just isn't the same as it used to be: PR people have taken over and emotion has been outlawed.

episodes.title: I've found the worst employee handbook ever
episodes.summary: Forty-one years ago, chairman Mao distributed 900m copies of The Little Red Book to the people of China. A couple of weeks ago, Deloitte distributed thousands of copies of The Little Blue Book of Strategy to its US employees. Apart from the difference in colour, the two books have much in common

episodes.title: Put real business on TV and I'll reach for the remote
episodes.summary: Business telly, so the newspapers tell us, is 'the new rock and roll'. While it isn't exactly cool, it is increasingly popular. But is it really about business?

episodes.title: Google will make recruits less frugal with the truth
episodes.summary: Lucy sees reasons for cheer in the new 'world without secrets'

episodes.title: Motivational memos must make their message clear
episodes.summary: Lucy asks 'what is the worst motivational memo ever?'

episodes.title: Private parties and shameless schmoozing
episodes.summary: The crossover of business and private parties creates problems for the guest. It is helpful to know which sort of do you are at, so you can behave accordingly, says Lucy Kellaway

episodes.title: Leisurely retirement? Think again
episodes.summary: When it comes to retirement, are you Buffet, Gates or potato?

episodes.title: The ups and downs of the daily grind
episodes.summary: Do you work well when you are miserable? Are happy workers the most productive? This week, Lucy keeps a diary to see how her moods affect her work.

episodes.title: Tone down the hatred and retain your dignity
episodes.summary: This week, Lucy looks at rage, pettiness and rivalry between companies.
